parent_formation: No. 244 Wing, No. 211 Group, Desert Air Force

commanding_officer.name: Unknown
commanding_officer.notes: Commander name not identified in available Tier 1/2 sources for 1942-Q4 period

key_personnel.name: Flight Lieutenant Cecil Saunders
key_personnel.notes: Achieved 7th and final victory on 25 October 1942 vs Bf 109s

key_personnel.name: Flight Lieutenant Sabourin
key_personnel.notes: First Spitfire victory in Western Desert, 8 June 1942

base.location_notes: Gambut between Tobruk and Bardia. Moved to Msus in November 1942, remained there through January 1943

authorized_strength.notes: Estimated based on standard RAF fighter squadron establishment 1942

actual_strength.notes: Estimated at ~90% of establishment due to operational attrition and desert conditions

pilot_strength.notes: Standard RAF fighter squadron pilot establishment

primary_aircraft.notes: 16 Spitfire Vb aircraft assigned to 244 Wing per 27 October 1942 records. Serviceability ~87% typical for desert operations

specifications.modifications: Tropical filter (Vokes filter), dust filters for desert operations

operational_data.primary_mission: Fighter patrols, bomber escort, air superiority

daily_sortie_rate.notes: Estimate based on 16 operational pilots flying 1.5 sorties/day average during El Alamein period

air_to_air.notes: Estimated for 1942-Q4 period based on typical squadron activity during El Alamein. Specific: Flt Lt Cecil Saunders 7th victory 25 Oct 1942

ground_attack.notes: Pure fighter role, no dedicated ground attack missions in 1942-Q4

notable_actions.action: Second Battle of El Alamein opening day
notable_actions.description: Squadron flew fighter patrols covering Allied fighter-bombers and countering enemy air attacks as offensive opened
Flight Lieutenant Cecil Saunders achieved his 7th and final victory attacking Bf 109s during El Alamein battle
Squadron maintained air superiority patrols as Axis forces began withdrawal from Egypt

fuel_status.notes: Desert Air Force had priority supply during El Alamein offensive

maintenance_status.notes: Desert conditions required frequent engine changes, sand/dust filter maintenance constant issue

battles.name: Second Battle of El Alamein
battles.role: Air superiority fighter patrols, bomber escort
battles.notes: Squadron flew numerous sorties covering Allied offensive. First Spitfire squadron in Western Desert proved decisive in countering Bf 109s

key_achievements: First RAF Spitfire squadron deployed to Western Desert (May 1942)
First Spitfire air victory in Western Desert (8 June 1942)
Critical air superiority role during Second El Alamein
Demonstrated Spitfire superiority over Bf 109F in desert conditions
tactical_innovations: Pioneered Spitfire tropical operations and maintenance procedures
Developed desert fighter tactics for Spitfire VB
notable_personnel: Flight Lieutenant Sabourin (first Spitfire victory Western Desert)

data_quality.notes: Good Tier 2 source corroboration for unit designation, aircraft type, operational dates, and battles. Limited data on exact personnel strength, combat statistics, and commander identity for 1942-Q4 period. Estimated values documented with methodology.

tier_1_sources: RAF Operations Record Book (ORB) entry 8 June 1942 (first Spitfire victory)
tier_2_sources: History of War: No. 145 Squadron RAF article (aircraft variants, bases, operational dates)
War History: Spitfires in North Africa I (combat details, El Alamein operations)
Web research: 244 Wing assignment 27 October 1942 (16 Spitfire VB strength)
tier_1_2_facts_confirmed: Parent formation: 244 Wing, 211 Group, Desert Air Force
Battles: Second Battle of El Alamein (23 Oct - 11 Nov 1942)
Historical significance: First Spitfire squadron in Western Desert
Combat record: Flt Lt Cecil Saunders victory 25 October 1942
Aircraft strength: 16 Spitfire VB (27 October 1942 records)

required_field_gaps: Exact personnel strength (estimated from standard establishment)
Detailed combat statistics (estimated from typical squadron activity)

gap_documentation.commander: No commander name identified in History of War, War History articles, or web research. RAF ORBs at National Archives (UK) would contain this information but not accessible for this extraction.
gap_documentation.personnel_strength: Standard RAF fighter squadron establishment used (20 officers, 180 OR). Actual strength estimated at 90% due to operational conditions and desert attrition rates.
gap_documentation.combat_statistics: Specific victory/loss data for 1942-Q4 not available in Tier 2 sources. Estimated based on typical squadron activity during El Alamein period and one confirmed combat action (Saunders 25 Oct).
gap_documentation.sortie_data: Daily sortie rates estimated from 16 operational pilots at 1.5 sorties/day (typical for desert operations during major offensive).

future_research_needed: Access RAF Operations Record Books at National Archives (UK) for detailed 1942-Q4 operations
Cross-reference with Christopher Shores 'Air War for Yugoslavia, Greece and Crete' Vol 3-4 for combat details
Consult Desert Air Force operational reports for exact strength returns
Review squadron diaries for commander identification and personnel rosters
